summary: This document contains due diligence research results for JeeperS, Inc., including searches for negative media, public records, and court cases. The findings indicate no significant negative media or alerts, but several records related to judgments and liens against the company are detailed. The document emphasizes the importance of compliance and thorough review of results. This document contains various filings related to judgments and liens against multiple entities, primarily associated with 'JEEPERS INC.' and its affiliates. It details debtor information, creditor information, and various financial filings across different states, including Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and Illinois. This document contains multiple UCC lien filings related to a company named Jeepers! Inc. and its secured party, Leasing Technologies International, Inc. The filings detail various equipment leases and financial statements, including original filing numbers, dates, and collateral information. This document contains various UCC lien filings related to JEEPERS, INC. and associated parties. It details the debtor information, secured parties, filing dates, and collateral descriptions for multiple filings across different states. The document highlights the financial relationships and obligations of JEEPERS, INC. with various financial institutions. This document contains various UCC lien filings related to multiple entities named Jeepers Inc. and its affiliates, detailing secured parties, filing dates, and collateral information. It includes records of assignments, amendments, and initial filings across different states, primarily focusing on equipment and financial interests. This document contains various property assessment records for properties owned by John M. Conroy in Montgomery County, MD, and other related entities. It includes assessed values, market values, and addresses associated with these properties, as well as some business information related to 'JEEPERS, INC.' and its associates. This document is a court opinion regarding a motion for summary judgment in a case involving Loadman Group, L.L.C. and Banco Popular North America. The court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment, concluding that the plaintiffs lacked standing to pursue their claims due to a bankruptcy filing by one of the plaintiffs, Eric J. Loadman. The document details the procedural history and factual background of the case, including the environmental issues related to a loan application. This document discusses the summary judgment motions related to a breach of contract case involving Loadman and Banco. It outlines the failure of Loadman to meet loan conditions and the implications of environmental assessments on the loan process. The court ultimately grants summary judgment on several claims due to lack of evidence and the statute of frauds. This document is a court ruling regarding a motion for summary judgment in a case involving breach of fiduciary duty and promissory estoppel claims. The court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment, dismissing the plaintiffs' claims due to insufficient evidence and procedural issues related to the amendment of complaints. The ruling emphasizes the importance of adhering to procedural rules in legal claims. This document discusses a legal case involving the Swentos and CEC regarding a personal guaranty related to a lease agreement. The court ruled on various motions, including a motion in limine to exclude certain evidence and the validity of the Swentos' claims regarding changes to their obligations under the guaranty. Ultimately, the court affirmed the judgment against the Swentos for unpaid rent and property damages. This document discusses a legal case involving Hanlin-Rainaldi Construction Corporation and Jeepers, Inc. regarding a breach of contract and settlement agreements related to construction projects. The court examines various motions for summary judgment and the application of the parol evidence rule in determining the obligations of the parties under their agreements. This document discusses various legal cases involving Jeepers, Inc., including contract disputes and negligence claims. It references multiple court cases and legal principles related to contract interpretation and the application of the parol evidence rule. The document also includes details about specific cases, their statuses, and involved parties. This document discusses a workers' compensation case involving a claimant's ability to return to work after an industrial accident. It reviews medical opinions from various doctors regarding the claimant's condition and the validity of their assessments, ultimately affirming the Deputy Commissioner's decision to favor the opinions of the treating physicians over those of the employer's doctors.

events.title: Civil Suit Filing
events.description: A civil suit was filed against JEEPERS INC. with a judgment amount of $1,105,000.

events.title: Judgment Filing
events.description: A judgment was filed against JEEPERS INC. for an amount of $7,993.

events.title: UCC Lien Filing
events.description: An initial UCC lien filing was made by IMPERIAL BANK against JEEPERS INC.

events.title: Complaint Filed
events.description: Loadman Group and Eric J. Loadman filed a complaint against Banco Popular North America.

events.title: Amended Complaint Filed
events.description: An amended complaint was filed by Loadman and Loadman Group alleging various claims against Banco.

events.title: Bankruptcy Filed
events.description: Eric J. Loadman filed a Voluntary Petition for Chapter 7 Bankruptcy.

events.title: Summary Judgment Motion Filed
events.description: Banco Popular filed a motion for summary judgment arguing that Loadman lacked standing due to bankruptcy.

events.title: Trustee Employment Granted
events.description: The bankruptcy court granted a motion for the bankruptcy trustee to employ plaintiffs' counsel as special counsel.

events.title: Loan Denial
events.description: Banco's Diane Gallion issued a letter denying the loans due to environmental contamination.

events.title: Proposal of Lease Alternative
events.description: Gallion proposed a lease alternative for Loadman to expedite the loan process.

events.title: Assurances from Banco
events.description: Banco's representatives assured Loadman that the original loan deal could proceed.

events.title: Draft LSA Report Submission
events.description: Loadman emailed a draft Limited Site Assessment report to Banco and Ansell.

events.title: Banco's Decision on Loan
events.description: Banco informed Loadman that it would not proceed with the loan due to environmental issues.

events.title: Lawsuit Filed
events.description: Loadman filed a lawsuit against Banco regarding the loan.

events.title: Ruling on Summary Judgment
events.description: The court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment, dismissing the plaintiffs' claims.

events.title: Trial Date
events.description: The trial was scheduled to determine the extent of damages owed by the Swentos to CEC.

events.title: Attorney Fees Granted
events.description: The circuit court granted CEC's request for attorney fees following the judgment against the Swentos.

events.title: Lease Agreement between Jeepers and Concord Mills
events.description: Jeepers and Concord Mills entered into a ten-year lease agreement for a business establishment at Concord Mills Mall.

events.title: Contract Agreement between Jeepers and Hanlin-Rainaldi
events.description: Jeepers entered into an agreement with Hanlin-Rainaldi for construction services at Concord Mills Mall.

events.title: Settlement Agreement between Jeepers and Hanlin-Rainaldi
events.description: Jeepers and Hanlin-Rainaldi entered into a settlement agreement acknowledging a debt of $708,084.

events.title: Second Settlement Agreement
events.description: Hanlin-Rainaldi, Jeepers, and Concord Mills entered into a second settlement agreement to resolve disputed claims.

events.title: Lawsuit Filed by Hanlin-Rainaldi
events.description: Hanlin-Rainaldi filed a lawsuit against Jeepers in the Franklin County Court of Common Pleas for breach of contract.

events.title: August 2001 Agreement
events.description: The court discusses the interpretation of the August 2001 agreement between Hanlin-Rainaldi and Jeepers.

events.title: Claimant Injury
events.description: A claimant sustained a compensable injury by accident to his head, neck, shoulder, back, and hip.

events.title: Return to Work Evaluation
events.description: The claimant was evaluated for a return to work after sustaining injuries.

events.title: Claimant's Maximum Medical Improvement
events.description: The claimant was assessed for maximum medical improvement following treatment for work-related injuries.

events.title: Independent Medical Examination
events.description: An independent medical examination was conducted to assess the claimant's condition.

events.title: Dr. Ross Addendum Report
events.description: Dr. Ross wrote an addendum to his initial report after reviewing Dr. Sautter's conclusions.

events.title: Dr. Ross Second Addendum
events.description: Dr. Ross issued a second addendum addressing recent reports from Dr. Sautter and Dr. Holzer.

events.title: Claimant's Evaluation
events.description: The claimant was evaluated and released to full duty by Dr. Goss.

Eric J. Loadman filed a complaint against Banco Popular North America alleging breach of contract related to a loan application.
Loadman filed for Chapter 7 Bankruptcy, which affected his standing in the lawsuit.
Banco Popular denied the loan application due to environmental contamination found on the properties involved in the loan.
The court granted Banco Popular's motion for summary judgment, concluding that Loadman lacked standing due to bankruptcy.
Tamara Miles Ogier was substituted as the trustee for Loadman after his bankruptcy filing.
Loadman was assured by Banco's representatives that the loan could proceed despite environmental concerns.
Banco ultimately decided not to proceed with the loan due to unresolved environmental issues.
Loadman failed to submit necessary documentation to Banco for the loan process.
The court granted summary judgment on several claims due to lack of evidence.
The statute of frauds barred Loadman's oral contract claims against Banco.
The court ruled that the plaintiffs did not provide sufficient evidence for their claims of promissory estoppel and breach of fiduciary duty.
The ruling emphasized that new claims cannot be introduced at the summary judgment stage without proper amendment of the complaint.
The case was dismissed based on procedural grounds and lack of evidence.
The Swentos filed their fourth amended affirmative defenses on July 19, 2006.
The court granted CEC's motion in limine to exclude evidence relating to an alleged increase in risk on August 8, 2006.
The jury found CEC's damages for unpaid rent and property damage to be $246,588.38 against the Swentos.
The Swentos' arguments regarding the discharge of their obligations under the guaranty were rejected by the court.
The court affirmed the judgment against the Swentos for unpaid rent and property damages.
Hanlin-Rainaldi Construction Corporation is appealing a judgment regarding a breach of contract case against Jeepers, Inc.
Jeepers, Inc. failed to pay Hanlin-Rainaldi for services rendered, leading to a lawsuit.
Multiple settlement agreements were executed between Hanlin-Rainaldi and Jeepers, acknowledging debts owed.
The court examined the application of the parol evidence rule in determining the obligations under the agreements.
Kristy Krull, the comptroller of Hanlin-Rainaldi, provided an affidavit regarding payment issues.
The document discusses the interpretation of an August 2001 agreement between Hanlin-Rainaldi and Jeepers.
Multiple legal cases involving Jeepers, Inc. are referenced, including negligence claims and contract disputes.
The claimant in a workers' compensation case sustained injuries on May 13, 2004, and underwent various medical evaluations.
Dr. David G. Goss and other medical professionals provided treatment and evaluations for the claimant's injuries.
Several cases involving Jeepers have been disposed of, including settlements and judgments.
The Deputy Commissioner found that the employer failed to prove that the claimant was released to his pre-injury employment.
Dr. Goss's release was deemed invalid and afforded little weight in the decision-making process.
The claimant was diagnosed with multiple complaints related to an industrial accident by Dr. Holzer.
